newsitem.title: GERMANY: Kinkel backs Plavsic in Bosnian power struggle.
newsitem.headline: Kinkel backs Plavsic in Bosnian power struggle.

text.p: German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel said on Saturday he believed Bosnian Serb President Biljana Plavsic had acted legally by dissolving parliament, despite a constitutional court ruling to the contrary.

Kinkel said he backed the view of the international High Representative to Bosnia, Carlos Westendorp, that the court had reached its decision under pressure from former Bosnian Serb president Radovan Karadzic, Plavsic's arch enemy.

"There are signs that the verdict was influenced by Karadzic and his followers and that pressure was exerted on certain members of the court," Kinkel told reporters after a meeting with Croatian Foreign Minister Mate Granic.
The Bosnian Serb Constitutional Court ruled on Friday that Plavsic's decision to disband the Serb parliament and call early elections was not in harmony with the constitution.
Kinkel said the Bosnian Serbs would remain isolated as long as Karadzic, who has been indicted by the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, continued to pull the strings behind the scenes.
